audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker who sounds exhausted, referencing a long show and mentioning Roman Reigns and Brock Lesnar. He adds that he is "exhausted no more." He continues, noting, "No joke, as Roman is in the ring, his music is playing, his awesome new operatic music is playing." He explains that he received an "are you still there?" message due to the show's length. He then mentions Paul Heyman doing Roman Reigns's entrance. The speaker indicates it's every year.

The clip starts with a male speaker expressing admiration for Paul Heyman, noting he was "on fire tonight," before shifting focus to Roman Reigns' entrance, characterized by the terms "undisputed reigning defending" with a tone of enthusiastic commentary.  Following this, there is mention of the microphone being passed back to the regular ring announcer and then taken away by "Brock."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing Paul Heyman and Brock Lesnar, noting that Heyman was initially paired with Lesnar because Lesnar "wasn't very good at talking," while Heyman was. The speaker continues, emphasizing that Lesnar learned and worked on his speaking skills, eventually doing his own ring intro. He then states, "it's a Paul Heyman imitation, and it's gold."

The clip begins with two men in conversation. One man, speaking in a casual tone, comments on the ironic nature of a situation, noting how someone did something on a previous occasion and then repeated it shortly after. The second man replies in agreement that the repeat "didn't suck," and the first responds by noting that the fans helped along. The second man declares someone as the "Cowboy country ass kicker who's gonna kick your ass," and then indicates how someone cut to Roman and Hayman. The first man mentions that Hayman is butt hurt at this imitation of himself, saying they were friends for two decades and he can't believe this person is making fun of him.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker adopting an enthusiastic tone, summarizing a wrestling match by describing how it felt like the "biggest match in WrestleMania history." He references the "stupeendous title" and how it felt like a "heavyweight championship match." The speaker then talks about the wrestlers in the match, noting it's one of only a few times two people have had three WrestleMania matches. He references prior wrestling matches before the clip ends.

The clip begins with a male speaker recalling the origin of the phrase "Suplex City, Bitch," mentioning Brock Lesnar, a match in San Francisco, and WrestleMania. His tone is conversational and narrative, giving a brief history of the phrase. Afterwards, another male voice agrees by simply saying, "Yeah." The narrative speaker then concludes that they have reached the end of their "tale."

The clip features a single male speaker describing a wrestling match in an enthusiastic tone. He recounts the slugfest, mentioning spears, F5s, Superman punches, suplexes, and a spear into the barricade. The speaker goes on to describe how the referee is taken out and a low blow occurs, followed by Roman trying another spear, which Brock counters. The speaker indicates Brock's eyes were bugging out. He describes how Roman gets to the ropes. The speaker recounts Roman pleading with Heyman about his shoulder, and Heyman's encouraging response. Finally, the speaker says that Roman slips behind Brock and hits one last spear, winning the match.

The clip starts with one male speaker who describes something as "a main event of the biggest show of the year" in an excited tone. Another male voice responds, agreeing that it was "exactly what I expected," then proceeds to describe a wrestling match, using phrases like "Roman Brock matches", "big move", "kick out of a finish", and noting that some people "really didn't like the match." This speaker has a slightly more measured tone, but with a similar enthusiastic energy. He concludes by stating that he "thought it was good" and that they "delivered".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker expressing his positive opinion of a match, stating he doesn't know what people expected but emphasizing it was a clash between "two big dudes clubbering each other" and lived up to its nature. A second male speaker then asks another person, presumably named Mark, for his thoughts. Mark describes something, noting the prevalence of a certain occurrence of a person getting "punched in the dick".

The clip opens with a male speaker in a casual tone recounting a conversation with someone named Brian about wearing cups. He explains that Brian claimed getting punched in the groin with a cup on would "cut your dick off". Another male voice, also casual, interjects saying "I just watched Jackass, cups are not foolproof". The first speaker agrees, while another speaker disagrees with his initial statement about getting your dick cut off. He explains his belief came from when he was in school, suggesting a cup would cut your dick off if kicked up at the right angle. A fourth male speaker then responds to this theory by calling it "spoken like a man who never actually played sports," further adding, "spoken like a man who never wore a cup." The fourth speaker states that he never wore a cup but also never got hit in the balls because he "avoided it".

The clip starts with two men conversing in a casual tone about a match they've seen repeatedly. One man summarizes the predictable sequence of events in the match: suplexes, German maneuvers, spears, a glove matching shoes and underpants. He expresses his familiarity with the match. Another man agrees, mentioning WrestleMania and a variety of other shows. The first man confirms he has seen the match and the conversation ends.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker questioning who Roman's next challenger will be. Another male replies with uncertainty. The first male then offers several names of possible challengers. Subsequently, another male speaker suggests Edge, and after some sounds of disapproval, he suggests "the Edge Lords", followed by laughter. One of the men suggests that Theory should be able to work on both shows because he's the dual champion and doesn't need to be limited to one show. One of the men asserts they have been planning this match for months.

The clip starts with a conversation between two male speakers discussing Paul introducing Roman as the undisputed WWE Universal Champion. One male recounts that when Roman won, they called him the new Undisputed Universal Champion, repeating what Paul had already said. Further emphasizing this point, a third male was also calling him WWE Universal Champion, which he was already known as. Frustration can be heard in one male's tone as he expresses exasperation at the fact they called him the same thing.

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing disappointment, anticipating something new like a belt or a name change, but then noting that instead, things just stumbled forward and the person in question holds both belts. Another male speaker interjects, mentioning a Twitter source. The first speaker then asks if they got an answer, and the second speaker says the first won't like the answer.

The clip begins with a discussion about wrestling. Two men speak about "the Tribal Chief Roman Reigns" defeating Brock Lesnar. They joke about the title, "undisputed WWE Universal Champion". One suggests "just world champ." The other wonders what's bigger than a universe and a suggestion is made, multiverse champion. Then they say that when he fights someone on Mars he can be the - but one of them interrupts to call it "dumb." They settle on world champ. The other agrees, it's "super dumb" to talk about.

The audio clip begins with two male speakers; one excitedly instructs listeners to check WWE's Twitter for a photo of Brock Lesnar putting Roman Reigns in a Kimura, emphasizing that "Brock's eyes are universal." The second speaker expresses a reaction, possibly indicating agreement or understanding. The first speaker then declares that they're going to retweet something.

The audio clip starts with two male voices discussing Brock Lesnar and a “baby face cowboy” persona. They agree Lesnar is great. The conversation transitions into bats and their ability to fly. One of the speakers states that "a bat cannot stand and then take off" and must "fall from a great height and then fly." The other male voice reacts in understanding. One speaker declares that Sting is now a bat and relays that Sting "did not jump through these tables" but rather "he fell." The clip concludes with an advertisement from a male speaker promoting an audio streaming subscription of wrestling content, accompanied by background music that is upbeat, in HD, and seems like a theme.
